description: From Middle English schaft, from Old English sÄ‹eaft, from Proto-West Germanic *skaft, from Proto-Germanic *skaftaz. Cognate with Dutch schacht, German German Schaft, Swedish skaft.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The entire body of a long weapon, such as an arrow.
examples: His sleep, his meat, his drink, is him bereft, / That lean he wax, and dry as is a shaft.

entries.meaning: The long, narrow, central body of a spear, arrow, or javelin.
examples: Her hand slipped off the javelin's shaft towards the spearpoint and that's why her score was lowered.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Anything cast or thrown as a spear or javelin.
examples: And the thunder, / Winged with red lightning and impetuous rage, / Perhaps hath spent his shafts.

entries.meaning: Any long thin object, such as the handle of a tool, one of the poles between which an animal is harnessed to a vehicle, the driveshaft of a motorized vehicle with rear-wheel drive, an axle, etc.
A beam or ray of light.
examples: Isn't that shaft of light from that opening in the cave beautiful?

entries.meaning: The main axis of a feather.
examples: I had no idea that they removed the feathers' shafts to make the pillows softer!

entries.meaning: (lacrosse) The long narrow body of a lacrosse stick.
examples: Sarah, if you wear gloves your hands might not slip on your shaft and you can up your game, girl!

entries.meaning: A vertical or inclined passage sunk into the earth as part of a mine
examples: Your grandfather used to work with a crane hauling ore out of the gold mine's shafts.

entries.meaning: A vertical passage housing a lift or elevator; a liftshaft.
examples: Darn it, my keys fell through the gap and into the elevator shaft.

entries.meaning: A ventilation or heating conduit; an air duct.
examples: Our parrot flew into the air duct and got stuck in the shaft.

entries.meaning: (architecture) Any column or pillar, particularly the body of a column between its capital and pedestal.
examples: Bid time and nature gently spare / The shaft we raise to thee.

entries.meaning: The main cylindrical part of the penis.
examples: The female labia minora is homologous to the penis shaft skin of males.

entries.meaning: The chamber of a blast furnace.
(meteorology) A relatively small area of precipitation that an onlook can discern from the dry surrounding area.

verbs.description: shaft (third-person singular simple present shafts, present participle shafting, simple past and past participle shafted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To fuck over; to cause harm to, especially through deceit or treachery.
examples: Your boss really shafted you by stealing your idea like that.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To fuck; to have sexual intercourse with.
examples: Turns out my roommate was shafting my girlfriend.
